task: The user has been unable to send MMS messages using their messaging app for the past few hours. Customer name: John Smith, phone number: 555-123-2002, current location: abroad in France. They will consider the issue resolved when an MMS message can be successfully sent.

messages.content: Hi, I‚Äôm having trouble sending MMS messages through my messaging app. It‚Äôs been a few hours and I still can‚Äôt send any pictures. Can you help me fix this?

I can help. First, I need to identify your account and the line you‚Äôre using.

- Please provide either:
  - The phone number of the line you‚Äôre trying to send MMS from, or
  - Your full name and date of birth (YYYY-MM-DD)

To speed things up, please also confirm a few details:
1) Are you able to make/receive regular calls on this line?
2) When you‚Äôre not on Wi‚ÄëFi, can other apps use mobile data (for example, load a webpage)?
3) Are you currently at home/in your normal area, or traveling away from your usual network?

Once I have this, I‚Äôll run some checks and guide you through the fixes.
messages.reasoning_content: Plan: Start MMS troubleshooting by identifying the customer and gathering basic info. Ask for full name + DOB or the phone number on the line. Ask whether cellular calls work and whether other apps use mobile data. Ask whether Wi-Fi Calling is enabled. Then proceed with step-by-step checks using diagnostic tools once I can execute actions (via user or tools). Focus on prerequisites: service, mobile data, data roaming if applicable, correct APN/MMSC, not on 2G, messaging app permissions, and possibly Wi-Fi Calling interference. Avoid subjective comments and follow the tech support policy sequentially.

Thanks for confirming. Since you don‚Äôt have cellular service, let‚Äôs run a quick check on the phone status first, then we‚Äôll fix it step by step.

Please perform these checks on your phone and tell me what you see:
1) Check the status bar icons:

2) SIM status:

3) Wi‚ÄëFi is off and mobile data is off:

Once you share what you see in steps 1‚Äì2, I‚Äôll guide you through the exact next actions. Common fixes include turning off Airplane Mode (if it‚Äôs on) or reseating the SIM if it shows as missing. If needed, we‚Äôll also verify APN settings and ensure data roaming is enabled on the device.

messages.content: Status Bar: ‚úàÔ∏è Airplane Mode | üîã 80%
On my status bar, I see that Airplane Mode is enabled (there‚Äôs an airplane icon). I don‚Äôt see any signal bars or network icons like ‚Äú5G,‚Äù ‚Äú4G/LTE,‚Äù or ‚Äú3G.‚Äù What should I do next?

Please turn off Airplane Mode on your phone now. That should restore cellular service.

After you turn it off:
- Check the status bar again. Do you see signal bars appear and a network type like ‚Äú5G,‚Äù ‚Äú4G/LTE,‚Äù or ‚Äú3G‚Äù?
- Try to make a quick test call and also confirm mobile data works by loading a webpage with Wi‚ÄëFi off.

If service comes back, try sending an MMS again. If you still don‚Äôt get service after turning Airplane Mode off, let me know what you see in the status bar and we‚Äôll continue troubleshooting.

I‚Äôve turned off Airplane Mode, but the status bar now shows ‚ÄúNo Signal‚Äù and data is still disabled. I‚Äôm not seeing any network type like ‚Äú4G/LTE,‚Äù ‚Äú5G,‚Äù or ‚Äú3G.‚Äù What should I try next?

Got it. Since you still see ‚ÄúNo Signal,‚Äù let‚Äôs check the SIM and a few settings.

Please run these checks and tell me what you see:
1) SIM status:
   - Do you see any ‚ÄúNo SIM‚Äù or ‚ÄúSIM locked‚Äù warning on the phone? If your phone has a SIM status screen, please check it and share what it shows (Active/Missing/Locked).

2) Data roaming on the device:
   - In your phone‚Äôs mobile network settings, make sure Data Roaming is turned ON. It‚Äôs required while abroad.

3) Network mode:
   - Check the preferred network type. If it‚Äôs set to 2G/3G only, switch it to a mode that includes 4G/5G (e.g., ‚Äú4G/5G preferred‚Äù or ‚Äú5G/4G/3G/2G Auto‚Äù).

4) Reboot:
   - After toggling the above settings, restart your phone and wait a minute for it to reconnect to the local network.

If the SIM shows as missing or you still have ‚ÄúNo Signal‚Äù after these steps, I can guide you to reseat the SIM. If the SIM shows locked, let me know and I‚Äôll escalate for assistance.
messages.reasoning_content: User has No Signal after disabling Airplane Mode while roaming abroad. Next steps per policy: check SIM status, then consider reseat SIM or escalation if locked; also verify data roaming is on and network mode preference not set to 2G/3G only. Ask user to perform check_sim_status and report back.

messages.content: No SIM card detected in the phone.
My phone is showing that there‚Äôs no SIM card detected‚Äîit says ‚ÄúNo SIM.‚Äù What should I do next to fix this?

Let‚Äôs reseat the SIM card first. This often resolves detection issues.

Please follow these steps:
1) Power off your phone completely.
2) Remove the SIM card tray using the SIM eject tool (or a small paperclip).
3) Take out the SIM card, check for any visible damage, and gently wipe the metal contacts with a dry, soft cloth.
4) Reinsert the SIM card firmly and correctly in the tray, then push the tray back in until it clicks.
5) Power the phone back on and wait 1‚Äì2 minutes for it to detect the SIM.

After it restarts:
- Check the status bar. Do you see signal bars and a network type now (5G/4G/3G)?
- Try making a test call and loading a webpage with Wi‚ÄëFi off.
- Try sending an MMS.

If you still see ‚ÄúNo SIM‚Äù after reseating, let me know. In that case, I‚Äôll need to escalate this to technical support for further assistance.
messages.reasoning_content: User sees ‚ÄúNo SIM.‚Äù Next step per policy is to reseat the SIM card via reseat_sim_card, then reboot. After reseating, confirm SIM detected, signal bars, network type, calls/data, then MMS. If still missing, escalate to technical support.

Great‚Äîsince you now have strong 5G signal, let‚Äôs confirm mobile data is working and then test MMS.

Please do the following:
1) Turn mobile data ON in your settings.
2) Make sure Data Roaming is ON (required while abroad).

Your messaging app cannot send MMS messages.
I‚Äôve turned on mobile data and enabled data roaming. I have a strong 5G signal, but my messaging app still can‚Äôt send MMS messages. What should I check or do next?

Let‚Äôs check a few specific settings that affect MMS. Please go through these and tell me what you find:

1) MMS capability test:
   - Some phones show an ‚ÄúMMS not available‚Äù or ‚ÄúCan‚Äôt send MMS‚Äù notice when attempting. Do you see any specific error in your messaging app?

2) Network mode:
   - Confirm your preferred network mode includes 3G/4G/5G. If it‚Äôs set to 2G only, switch it to a mode that includes 4G/5G.

3) APN settings:
   - Open your mobile network settings and check the APN. Look for an MMSC URL field. If it‚Äôs blank or looks incorrect, reset the APN to the carrier defaults. After resetting, you‚Äôll need to reboot the phone.

4) Wi‚ÄëFi Calling:
   - If Wi‚ÄëFi Calling is turned on, try turning it OFF temporarily. Some configurations interfere with MMS while roaming.

5) Messaging app permissions:
   - Check that your messaging app has permissions for Storage and SMS. If either is denied, grant them.

6) Final test:
   - After each adjustment, try sending a picture message.

Please let me know:
- What error/message you see when trying to send MMS now.
- Your current network mode setting.
- Whether the MMSC URL was missing or incorrect before/after resetting.
- Whether Wi‚ÄëFi Calling was on/off and if toggling it helped.
- The permissions status for Storage and SMS in your messaging app.

With those details, I can guide you to the next fix if needed.
messages.reasoning_content: Proceed to MMS troubleshooting via tech_support_policy. Ask user to run checks that the tools simulate: can_send_mms, check_network_status (ensure not 2G), check_apn_settings (MMSC), check_wifi_calling_status (disable if ON), check_app_permissions for messaging (storage, sms). Then step through fixes: reset_apn_settings + reboot, toggle_wifi_calling OFF, grant permissions. Since tools are simulated, instruct user to perform those steps on device.

When I try to send an MMS, it just fails without a specific error message. Would you like me to enable Storage and SMS permissions for the messaging app next?

After that:

If it still fails:

- If needed, we can reset the APN to defaults and reboot the device.

Let me know how it goes.

I‚Äôve granted Storage and SMS permissions to the messaging app, and mobile data is still working on 5G. However, I‚Äôm still unable to send MMS messages.

What should I try next‚Äîshould I temporarily turn off Wi-Fi Calling, or would you like me to reset the APN settings and reboot the device? This is getting a bit frustrating.

I understand this is frustrating. Let‚Äôs do the less disruptive step first:

1) Temporarily turn off Wi‚ÄëFi Calling, then try sending a picture message again.

If MMS still fails:
2) Reset the APN to defaults, then reboot the device. After it restarts, with Wi‚ÄëFi off and mobile data on, try sending an MMS one more time.

A couple of quick checks while you‚Äôre at it:
- Make sure you have enough free storage on the phone.
- Try sending a very small photo to rule out file size issues.

Please let me know the result after each step. If the issue persists after both Wi‚ÄëFi Calling off and APN reset/reboot, I‚Äôll escalate to technical support for deeper investigation.
